title: English
instruction: Read the passage and answer the question that follows.
passage: You all know how friendly we are with Okperi. Do you think that Umuaro man who goes to prison there will come back alive? But that part, do you forget that this is the moon for planting? Do you want to grow this year's crops in the prison house in a land where your fathers owe a cow? I speak as your elder brother, I have traveled in Olu and I have traveled in Igbo, and I can tell you that there is no escape from the white man. He has come, where suffering knocks at your door and you say there is no seat left for him, he tells you not worry because he has brought the legs, I saw with my own eyes what the white man did to Abame. Then I knew there was no escape. As daylight chases away darkness, so will the white man drive away all our customs. I know that as I say it now it passes by our ears but it will happen. The white man has power which comes from God and it burns like fire. This is the God about whom we preach about every eight day. Unachukwu's opponents were now shouting that this was a meeting of an age group that they had not assembled to join with him in chewing the seeds of foolishness which they called their new religion. We talking about the white man's road; said voids above the others. Yes we are talking about the white man's road. But when the roof and walls of a house fall in, the ceiling is not left standing, the white man, the new religion, the soldiers, the new road they are all part of the same thing. The white man has a gun, a matchet, a bow and carries fire in his mouth. He does not fight with one weapon alone.
question: The dominant subject of this passage is the:

question: 'There is no escape from the white man' in the passage means that:
optionA: White man will send the people to prison
optionB: White man can kill all the people with his gun
optionC: People are only trying to run away from the white man
optionD: People must accept the white man
correctAnswer: People must accept the white man

title: English
instruction: Read the dialogue and answer the question that follows.
passage: Manager: Mr. Mbu, not describe you as an inefficient worker; I therefore find it difficult to understand why the conference room is so untidy, inspite of the fact that I reminded you of the meeting scheduled to take place there this afternoon. Secretary: Sir, I did instruct the cleaner to tidy up the place before the meeting scheduled to take place there this afternoon. Manager: Sir, I do see what else I could have done, short of doing the job myself. The cleaner is a six-footer and I could not have intimated him physically. Manager: I see, I wait your formal complain against the cleaner, but I shall not forget that you allowed a board meeting to take place in an untidy place in an untidy conference room.
question: The relationship between the manager and his secretary, as revealed in the passage, could be said to be:

title: English
instruction: Read the dialogue and answer the question that follows.
passage: Manager: Mr. Mbu, not describe you as an inefficient worker; I therefore find it difficult to understand why the conference room is so untidy, inspite of the fact that I reminded you of the meeting scheduled to take place there this afternoon. Secretary: Sir, I did instruct the cleaner to tidy up the place before the meeting scheduled to take place there this afternoon. Manager: Sir, I do see what else I could have done, short of doing the job myself. The cleaner is a six-footer and I could not have intimated him physically. Manager: I see, I wait your formal complain against the cleaner, but I shall not forget that you allowed a board meeting to take place in an untidy place in an untidy conference room.
question: 'I would not describe you as an inefficient worker...' suggests that the manager:
optionA: is quite pleased with the level of diligence of his secretary
optionB: Has had cause in the past to complain against his secretary
optionC: is dissatisfied with the level of performance of his secretary
optionD: is non-committal over the efficiency of his secretary
correctAnswer: is quite pleased with the level of diligence of his secretary

optionA: should have, if possible personally cleaned the conference room
optionB: should have ensured that someone else cleaned the conference room
optionC: should have ensured that the cleaner did his job
correctAnswer: should have ensured that the cleaner did his job

title: English
instruction: Read the dialogue and answer the question that follows.

Secretary: Sir, I did instruct the cleaner to tidy up the place before the meeting scheduled to take place there this afternoon. Manager: I see, I wait your formal complain against the cleaner, but I shall not forget that you allowed a board meeting to take place in an untidy place in an untidy conference room.
question: The secretary's attitude seems to be:
optionA: Manager Sir, you employed this huge and recalcitrant cleaner and I am not going to do his job for him
optionB: it is not the duty of a secretary to enforce the instructions he gives to his junior worker
optionC: I am a secretary by profession, not cleaner
optionD: it is not terribly important how tidy the conference room is
correctAnswer: it is not the duty of a secretary to enforce the instructions he gives to his junior worker

title: English
instruction: Read the dialogue and answer the question that follows.
passage: Manager: Mr. Mbu, not describe you as an inefficient worker; I therefore find it difficult to understand why the conference room is so untidy, inspite of the fact that I reminded you of the meeting scheduled to take place there this afternoon. Manager: Sir, I do see what else I could have done, short of doing the job myself. The cleaner is a six-footer and I could not have intimated him physically. Manager: I see, I wait your formal complain against the cleaner, but I shall not forget that you allowed a board meeting to take place in an untidy place in an untidy conference room.
question: The last comment by the manager suggests that he:
optionA: is going to hold the secretary responsible for what has happened
optionB: Is likely to reprimand both the secretary and the cleaner for dereliction duty
optionC: will punish the cleaner but warn the secretary
optionD: will warn the cleaner but punish the secretary
correctAnswer: is going to hold the secretary responsible for what has happened

title: English
instruction: Read the passage and answer the question that follows.
passage: Primitive man was probably more concerned with fire as a source of warmth and as a means of cooking food than as a source of light. Before the discovered less laborious ways of making fire, he had to preserve it and when he went on a journey he carried a firebrand with him. His discovery that the firebrand, from which the tough may well have developed, could be used for illumination was probable incidental to the primary purpose of preserving a frame. Lamps, too, probable developed by accident. Early man may have has his first concept of lamp while watching a twig or fiber burning in the molten fat dropped from roasting carcass All he had to do was to fashion a vessel to contain fat and float read in it. Such lamps, which were made of hollowed stones or identical form up to quite recent times.
question: According to the passage, the torch probably developed from a:

instruction: Read the passage and answer the question that follows.
passage: Primitive man was probably more concerned with fire as a source of warmth and as a means of cooking food than as a source of light. Before the discovered less laborious ways of making fire, he had to preserve it and when he went on a journey he carried a firebrand with him. His discovery that the firebrand, from which the tough may well have developed, could be used for illumination was probable incidental to the primary purpose of preserving a frame. Lamps, too, probable developed by accident. Early man may have has his first concept of lamp while watching a twig or fiber burning in the molten fat dropped from roasting carcass All he had to do was to fashion a vessel to contain fat and float read in it. Such lamps, which were made of hollowed stones or identical form up to quite recent times.
question: Primitive man preserved fire because:
optionA: he used it for illumination during his travels
optionB: his method of making fire was laborious
optionC: he wanted to discover how to make a lamp
optionD: he wanted to develop the torch
correctAnswer: his method of making fire was laborious
